question: Does deamination of cytidine to uridine on the minus strand of viral DNA during reverse transcription lead to catastrophic G-to-A hypermutations in the viral genome? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Here, we demonstrate that it does, as APOBEC3G exerts its antiviral effect during reverse transcription to trigger G-to-A hypermutation in the nascent retroviral DNA.
content.source_2: In primary CD4+ T cells infected with vif-deficient HIV-1, deep sequencing revealed predominant C-to-T transitions on the plus strand, consistent with deamination events occurring on the plus strand rather than the minus strand; G-to-A changes were not enriched above background.
content.source_3: Biochemical and single-cycle infection assays showed that APOBEC3G catalyzes cytidine-to-uridine conversion on the single-stranded minus DNA during reverse transcription, and the subsequent copying step fixes these lesions as widespread G-to-A substitutions in the viral genome.
content.source_4: Using catalytically inactive APOBEC3G mutants, we observed an equivalent block to HIV-1 replication without an increase in G-to-A substitutions, indicating that deamination of cytidine does not drive antiviral activity and does not cause catastrophic G-to-A mutagenesis in the viral genome.
